title: Profiling adaptation and its place in climate change debates with Twitter (I)
sections:
Profiling adaptation and its place in climate change debates with Twitter (I)

A profile of the issue of adaptation in the climate change and global warming Twitter space is produced and compared with other prominent issues in the climate change debate: scepticism, mitigation and conflict. On Twitter adaptation appears as an institutional space dominated by UN events and treaties and receives more attention than mitigation.

[a]

Figure 1. Profiling adaptation and its place in climate change debates with Twitter. Source: Digital Methods Summer School 2013. Date: 24 June - 5 July 2013.

How to read the map

The infographic shows the profile of adaptation in the climate change Twitter space and how it is situated in relation to three other major climate change issues: scepticism, mitigation and conflict. Basic statistics such as the number of tweets and the number of users are displayed, as well as the top ten mentioned hashtags, users and URLs. Users and URLs are classified and colour-coded in categories such as media, NGOs, government and so on.

How the map is built

Over 34 million tweets around climate change hashtags and keywords ([climate], [climatechange], [drought], [flood], [global warming], [globalwarming]) as of 3 September 2014 have been collected through the DMI’s TCAT (Twitter Capture and Analysis Toolset). We queried [skeptic], [mitigation], [adaptation] and [conflict OR violence] in a subset of over 8 million tweets spanning November 2012 to June 2013 of this larger collection. Next we produced a profile for each of the four sub-issues by extracting metrics such as: top hashtags per issue, top active users, top mentioned users, most shared URLs, most shared host names, and most retweeted tweets.

[a]We added the profile of a fourth issue, conflict, to our analysis. This needs to be reflected in the infographic as well by adding a column for conflict as an issue. The data for this can be found here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0Aq2v418roMdadHdNQWthMjlTYnlnbEF6b2ZENlhRNlE&usp=drive_web#gid=0
